title: Separation & Security
description: Explore how you feel when apart and what makes you feel secure.

questions.text: When we're apart, how do I typically feel?

therapeutic.rationale: How we feel during separation is one of the clearest indicators of attachment style. Secure attachers feel trusting calm; anxious attachers feel worry; avoidant attachers enjoy independence; anxious-preoccupied attachers miss intensely. This reveals the internal working model of relationships formed in childhood.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different separation feelings often create the pursuer-distancer dynamic. The one who misses constantly may feel abandoned by the independence-enjoyer; the independence-enjoyer may feel smothered by constant missing. Understanding these as attachment patterns rather than personal rejection helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared separation feelings suggest similar attachment orientations. If you both feel secure, separations are easy. If you both miss constantly, you may struggle with time apart together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner isn't around? Does your mind stay calm or does it wander to worries? What does your reaction tell you about your attachment?

questions.text: How do I react when I feel like you're pulling away?

therapeutic.rationale: Response to perceived distance reveals attachment activation. Space-givers show secure or avoidant patterns; reach-outers show anxious patterns; anxiety-and-reassurance seekers show anxious-preoccupied attachment; pull-backers show avoidant or fearful attachment. These responses often clash when partners differ.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different distance responses create relationship cycles. The reach-outer's attempts may feel like pursuit to the pull-backer, who retreats more, triggering more reaching out. Recognizing this cycle is the first step to breaking it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared distance responses can help (two space-givers respect boundaries) or create problems (two pull-backers may never reconnect). Awareness of your shared pattern matters.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you sense your partner withdrawing, what's your instinct? Does that response bring you closer or push you apart? Where did you learn this pattern?

questions.text: What's my biggest fear in our relationship?

therapeutic.rationale: Core relationship fears shape attachment behavior. Abandonment fear drives pursuit and reassurance-seeking; independence-loss fear drives avoidance and boundary-setting; inadequacy fear drives perfectionism and people-pleasing; growing-apart fear drives connection maintenance. These fears usually trace to early experiences.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different core fears create different protective behaviors. The abandonment-fearer may cling while the independence-loser pulls away. Neither is wrong—both are protecting against their deepest wound.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared core fears suggest similar attachment wounds. You'll deeply understand each other's anxiety because you share it. Be careful not to accidentally trigger your shared vulnerability.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your deepest fear about relationships? Where did this fear originate? How does it show up in your current relationship?

questions.text: How do I feel about depending on you?
choices: I want to but it's hard

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort with dependency is a hallmark of attachment security. Secure attachers feel comfortable depending on others; cautious types protect themselves; avoidant attachers prefer self-reliance; anxious attachers want to depend but fear it. The ability to healthily depend on your partner while maintaining autonomy is the goal of secure attachment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different dependency comfort creates relationship tension. The comfortable-depender may feel rejected by the self-reliant partner's independence; the self-reliant may feel burdened by dependency. Both are coping strategies for the same underlying fear.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared dependency comfort suggests similar attachment styles. Two comfortable-dependers will interweave easily; two self-reliant types may maintain more parallel lives.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about needing your partner? Is it comfortable or threatening? Where did you learn your relationship to dependency?

questions.text: What makes me feel most secure in our relationship?

therapeutic.rationale: Security sources vary by attachment style. Consistent contact soothes anxious attachers; honesty builds trust for those with betrayal wounds; physical presence grounds touch-oriented people; shared plans reassure commitment-anxious people. Knowing your partner's security source helps you provide what they specifically need.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different security sources mean different things make you feel safe. Your partner's security source may not be yours—provide what they need, not what you would need.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared security sources mean you'll naturally reassure each other in the same way. You understand what creates safety because it's what creates safety for you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel most secure in love? When your partner does this, how does it affect you? What happens when this source of security is missing?
